headers.toc1: The Second Book of Moses, called Exodus
headers.mt1: The Second Book of Moses, called Exodus

verses.text:
Now these \add are\add* the names of the children of Israel,
which came into Egypt; every man and his household came with Jacob.
Reuben, Simeon, Levi, and Judah,
Issachar, Zebulun, and Benjamin,
Dan, and Naphtali, Gad, and Asher.

And all the souls that came out of the loins of Jacob were
seventy souls: for Joseph was in Egypt \add already\add*.\f + \fr 1.5 
\ft loins: Heb. thigh\f*
And Joseph died, and all his brethren, and all that generation.

¶ And the children of Israel were fruitful, and increased abundantly,
and multiplied, and waxed exceeding mighty; and the land was filled with them.
Now there arose up a new king over Egypt, which knew not Joseph.

And he said unto his people, Behold, the people of the children
of Israel \add are\add* more and mightier than we:

Come on, let us deal wisely with them; lest they multiply,
and it come to pass, that, when there falleth out any war, they join
also unto our enemies, and fight against us, and \add so\add* get them
up out of the land.

Therefore they did set over them taskmasters to afflict them with their
burdens. And they built for Pharaoh treasure cities, Pithom and Raamses.

But the more they afflicted them, the more they multiplied
and grew. And they were grieved because of the children of Israel.\f + \fr 1.12 
\ft But…: Heb. And as they afflicted them, so they multiplied, etc\f*

And the Egyptians made the children of Israel to serve with
rigour:

And they made their lives bitter with hard bondage, in morter,
and in brick, and in all manner of service in the field: all their
service, wherein they made them serve, \add was\add* with rigour.

¶ And the king of Egypt spake to the Hebrew midwives, of which the
name of the one \add was\add* Shiphrah, and the name of the other
Puah:

And he said, When ye do the office of a midwife to the Hebrew
women, and see \add them\add* upon the stools; if it \add be\add*
a son, then ye shall kill him: but if it \add be\add* a daughter,
then she shall live.

But the midwives feared God, and did not as the king of Egypt
commanded them, but saved the men children alive.

And the king of Egypt called for the midwives, and said unto them,
Why have ye done this thing, and have saved the men children alive?

And the midwives said unto Pharaoh, Because the Hebrew women
\add are\add* not as the Egyptian women; for they \add are\add* lively,
and are delivered ere the midwives come in unto them.

Therefore God dealt well with the midwives: and the people
multiplied, and waxed very mighty.

And it came to pass, because the midwives feared God, that he
made them houses.

And Pharaoh charged all his people, saying, Every son that is
born ye shall cast into the river, and every daughter ye shall save
alive.

And there went a man of the house of Levi, and took \add to
wife\add* a daughter of Levi.

And the woman conceived, and bare a son: and when she saw him that he
\add was a\add* goodly \add child\add*, she hid him three months.

And when she could not longer hide him, she took for him an
ark of bulrushes, and daubed it with slime and with pitch, and put
the child therein; and she laid \add it\add* in the flags by the
river’s brink.
And his sister stood afar off, to wit what would be done to him.

¶ And the daughter of Pharaoh came down to wash \add herself\add*
at the river; and her maidens walked along by the river’s side; and when she
saw the ark among the flags, she sent her maid to fetch it.

And when she had opened \add it\add*, she saw the child: and, behold, the
babe wept. And she had compassion on him, and said, This \add is
one\add* of the Hebrews’ children.

Then said his sister to Pharaoh’s daughter, Shall I go and
call to thee a nurse of the Hebrew women, that she may nurse the
child for thee?

And Pharaoh’s daughter said to her, Go. And the maid went and
called the child’s mother.

And Pharaoh’s daughter said unto her, Take this child away,
and nurse it for me, and I will give \add thee\add* thy wages. And the
woman took the child, and nursed it.

And the child grew, and she brought him unto Pharaoh’s daughter,
and he became her son. And she called his name Moses: and she said,
Because I drew him out of the water.\f + \fr 2.10  \ft Moses: that is, Drawn
out\f*

¶ And it came to pass in those days, when Moses was grown,
that he went out unto his brethren, and looked on their burdens:
and he spied an Egyptian smiting an Hebrew, one of his brethren.

And he looked this way and that way, and when he saw that
\add there was\add* no man, he slew the Egyptian, and hid him in the
sand.

And when he went out the second day, behold, two men of the
Hebrews strove together: and he said to him that did the wrong, Wherefore
smitest thou thy fellow?

And he said, Who made thee a prince and a judge over us? intendest
thou to kill me, as thou killedst the Egyptian? And Moses feared,
and said, Surely this thing is known.\f + \fr 2.14  \ft a prince: Heb. a man, a
prince\f*

Now when Pharaoh heard this thing, he sought to slay Moses.
But Moses fled from the face of Pharaoh, and dwelt in the land of
Midian: and he sat down by a well.

Now the priest of Midian had seven daughters: and they came
and drew \add water\add*, and filled the troughs to water their father’s
flock.\f + \fr 2.16  \ft priest: or, prince\f*

And the shepherds came and drove them away: but Moses stood
up and helped them, and watered their flock.

And when they came to Reuel their father, he said, How \add is it
that\add* ye are come so soon to day?\f + \fr 2.18  \ft Reuel: called also Jethro, or,
Jether\f*

And they said, An Egyptian delivered us out of the hand of the
shepherds, and also drew \add water\add* enough for us, and watered
the flock.

And he said unto his daughters, And where \add is\add* he? why
\add is\add* it \add that\add* ye have left the man? call him, that he may
eat bread.

And Moses was content to dwell with the man: and he gave Moses
Zipporah his daughter.

And she bare \add him\add* a son, and he called his name Gershom:
for he said, I have been a stranger in a strange land.\f + \fr 2.22 
\ft Gershom: that is, A stranger here\f*

¶ And it came to pass in process of time, that the king of
Egypt died: and the children of Israel sighed by reason of the bondage,
and they cried, and their cry came up unto God by reason of the bondage.

And God heard their groaning, and God remembered his covenant
with Abraham, with Isaac, and with Jacob.

And God looked upon the children of Israel, and God had respect unto
\add them\add*.\f + \fr 2.25  \ft had…: Heb. knew\f*

Now Moses kept the flock of Jethro his father in law, the priest
of Midian: and he led the flock to the backside of the desert, and
came to the mountain of God, \add even\add* to Horeb.

And the angel of the \nd LORD\nd* appeared unto him in a flame
of fire out of the midst of a bush: and he looked, and, behold, the
bush burned with fire, and the bush \add was\add* not consumed.

And Moses said, I will now turn aside, and see this great sight,
why the bush is not burnt.

And when the \nd LORD\nd* saw that he turned aside to see,
God called unto him out of the midst of the bush, and said, Moses,
Moses. And he said, Here \add am\add* I.

And he said, Draw not nigh hither: put off thy shoes from off thy
feet, for the place whereon thou standest \add is\add* holy ground.

Moreover he said, I \add am\add* the God of thy father, the
God of Abraham, the God of Isaac, and the God of Jacob. And Moses
hid his face; for he was afraid to look upon God.

And I am come down to deliver them out of the hand of the Egyptians,
and to bring them up out of that land unto a good land and a large,
unto a land flowing with milk and honey; unto the place of the Canaanites,
and the Hittites, and the Amorites, and the Perizzites, and the Hivites,
and the Jebusites.

Now therefore, behold, the cry of the children of Israel is
come unto me: and I have also seen the oppression wherewith the Egyptians
oppress them.

Come now therefore, and I will send thee unto Pharaoh, that thou mayest bring
forth my people the children of Israel out of Egypt.

¶ And Moses said unto God, Who \add am\add* I, that I should
go unto Pharaoh, and that I should bring forth the children of Israel
out of Egypt?

And he said, Certainly I will be with thee; and this \add shall
be\add* a token unto thee, that I have sent thee: When thou hast brought
forth the people out of Egypt, ye shall serve God upon this mountain.

And Moses said unto God, Behold, \add when\add* I come unto the
children of Israel, and shall say unto them, The God of your fathers
hath sent me unto you; and they shall say to me, What \add is\add*
his name? what shall I say unto them?

And God said unto Moses, I AM THAT I AM: and he said, Thus shalt thou
say unto the children of Israel, I AM hath sent me unto you.

And God said moreover unto Moses, Thus shalt thou say unto the
children of Israel, The \nd LORD\nd* God of your fathers, the God
of Abraham, the God of Isaac, and the God of Jacob, hath sent me unto you: this
\add is\add* my name for ever, and this \add is\add* my memorial
unto all generations.

Go, and gather the elders of Israel together, and say unto them, The
\nd LORD\nd* God of your fathers, the God of Abraham, of Isaac, and of
Jacob, appeared unto me, saying, I have surely visited you, and \add seen\add*
that which is done to you in Egypt:

And I have said, I will bring you up out of the affliction
of Egypt unto the land of the Canaanites, and the Hittites, and the
Amorites, and the Perizzites, and the Hivites, and the Jebusites,
unto a land flowing with milk and honey.

And they shall hearken to thy voice: and thou shalt come,
thou and the elders of Israel, unto the king of Egypt, and ye shall
say unto him, The \nd LORD\nd* God of the Hebrews hath met with us: and now let us
go, we beseech thee, three days’ journey into the wilderness, that we may
sacrifice to the \nd LORD\nd* our God.

¶ And I am sure that the king of Egypt will not let you go,
no, not by a mighty hand.\f + \fr 3.19  \ft no…: or, but by strong
hand\f*

And I will stretch out my hand, and smite Egypt with all my
wonders which I will do in the midst thereof: and after that he will let you
go.

And I will give this people favour in the sight of the Egyptians:
and it shall come to pass, that, when ye go, ye shall not go empty:

But every woman shall borrow of her neighbour, and of her that
sojourneth in her house, jewels of silver, and jewels of gold, and
raiment: and ye shall put \add them\add* upon your sons, and upon your
daughters; and ye shall spoil the Egyptians.\f + \fr 3.22  \ft the Egyptians: or,
Egypt\f*

And Moses answered and said, But, behold, they will not believe
me, nor hearken unto my voice: for they will say, The \nd LORD\nd*
hath not appeared unto thee.

And the \nd LORD\nd* said unto him, What \add is\add* that in thine
hand? And he said, A rod.

And he said, Cast it on the ground. And he cast it on the ground,
and it became a serpent; and Moses fled from before it.

And the \nd LORD\nd* said unto Moses, Put forth thine hand,
and take it by the tail. And he put forth his hand, and caught it, and it became a
rod in his hand:

That they may believe that the \nd LORD\nd* God of their fathers,
the God of Abraham, the God of Isaac, and the God of Jacob, hath
appeared unto thee.

¶ And the \nd LORD\nd* said furthermore unto him, Put now thine
hand into thy bosom. And he put his hand into his bosom: and when he
took it out, behold, his hand \add was\add* leprous as snow.

And he said, Put thine hand into thy bosom again. And he put
his hand into his bosom again; and plucked it out of his bosom, and, behold, it was turned
again as his \add other\add* flesh.

And it shall come to pass, if they will not believe thee, neither
hearken to the voice of the first sign, that they will believe the
voice of the latter sign.

And it shall come to pass, if they will not believe also these
two signs, neither hearken unto thy voice, that thou shalt take of the
water of the river, and pour \add it\add* upon the dry \add land:\add*
and the water which thou takest out of the river shall become blood
upon the dry \add land\add*.\f + \fr 4.9  \ft shall become: Heb. shall be and shall
be\f*

¶ And Moses said unto the \nd LORD\nd*, O my Lord, I \add am\add*
not eloquent, neither heretofore, nor since thou hast spoken unto thy
servant: but I \add am\add* slow of speech, and of a slow tongue.\f + \fr 4.10 
\ft eloquent: Heb. a man of words\f*\f + \fr 4.10  \ft heretofore: Heb. since yesterday, nor since the third
day\f*

And the 
d LORD
d* said unto him, Who hath made man’s mouth?
or who maketh the dumb, or deaf, or the seeing, or the blind? have not I the

d LORD
d*?

Now therefore go, and I will be with thy mouth, and teach
thee what thou shalt say.

And he said, O my Lord, send, I pray thee, by the hand \add of him
whom\add* thou wilt send.\f + \fr 4.13  \ft wilt: or, shouldest\f*

And the anger of the \nd LORD\nd* was kindled against Moses,
and he said, \add Is\add* not Aaron the Levite thy brother? I know
that he can speak well. And also, behold, he cometh forth to meet
thee: and when he seeth thee, he will be glad in his heart.

And thou shalt speak unto him, and put words in his mouth:
and I will be with thy mouth, and with his mouth, and will teach
you what ye shall do.

And he shall be thy spokesman unto the people: and he shall be,
\add even\add* he shall be to thee instead of a mouth, and thou shalt be to him instead of
God.

And thou shalt take this rod in thine hand, wherewith thou shalt
do signs.

¶ And Moses went and returned to Jethro his father in law,
and said unto him, Let me go, I pray thee, and return unto my brethren which
\add are\add* in Egypt, and see whether they be yet alive. And Jethro
said to Moses, Go in peace.\f + \fr 4.18  \ft Jethro: Heb. Jether\f*

And the \nd LORD\nd* said unto Moses in Midian, Go, return
into Egypt: for all the men are dead which sought thy life.

And Moses took his wife and his sons, and set them upon an
ass, and he returned to the land of Egypt: and Moses took the rod
of God in his hand.

And the \nd LORD\nd* said unto Moses, When thou goest to return
into Egypt, see that thou do all those wonders before Pharaoh, which I have
put in thine hand: but I will harden his heart, that he shall not let the
people go.

And thou shalt say unto Pharaoh, Thus saith the \nd LORD\nd*,
Israel \add is\add* my son, \add even\add* my firstborn:

And I say unto thee, Let my son go, that he may serve me: and if thou
refuse to let him go, behold, I will slay thy son, \add even\add*
thy firstborn.

¶ And it came to pass by the way in the inn, that the \nd LORD\nd*
met him, and sought to kill him.

Then Zipporah took a sharp stone, and cut off the foreskin
of her son, and cast \add it\add* at his feet, and said, Surely a
bloody husband \add art\add* thou to me.\f + \fr 4.25  \ft sharp…: or,
knife\f*\f + \fr 4.25  \ft cast…: Heb. made it touch\f*

So he let him go: then she said, A bloody husband \add thou
art\add*, because of the circumcision.

¶ And the \nd LORD\nd* said to Aaron, Go into the wilderness
to meet Moses. And he went, and met him in the mount of God, and
kissed him.

And Moses told Aaron all the words of the \nd LORD\nd* who had
sent him, and all the signs which he had commanded him.

¶ And Moses and Aaron went and gathered together all the elders
of the children of Israel:

And Aaron spake all the words which the \nd LORD\nd* had spoken
unto Moses, and did the signs in the sight of the people.

And the people believed: and when they heard that the \nd LORD\nd*
had visited the children of Israel, and that he had looked upon their
affliction, then they bowed their heads and worshipped.

And afterward Moses and Aaron went in, and told Pharaoh, Thus
saith the \nd LORD\nd* God of Israel, Let my people go, that they may hold a
feast unto me in the wilderness.

And Pharaoh said, Who \add is\add* the \nd LORD\nd*, that I should
obey his voice to let Israel go? I know not the \nd LORD\nd*, neither will I let
Israel go.

And they said, The God of the Hebrews hath met with us: let us
go, we pray thee, three days’ journey into the desert, and sacrifice
unto the \nd LORD\nd* our God; lest he fall upon us with pestilence,
or with the sword.

And the king of Egypt said unto them, Wherefore do ye, Moses
and Aaron, let the people from their works? get you unto your burdens.

And Pharaoh said, Behold, the people of the land now \add are\add*
many, and ye make them rest from their burdens.

And Pharaoh commanded the same day the taskmasters of the people,
and their officers, saying,

Ye shall no more give the people straw to make brick, as heretofore:
let them go and gather straw for themselves.

And the tale of the bricks, which they did make heretofore,
ye shall lay upon them; ye shall not diminish \add ought\add* thereof: for they
\add be\add* idle; therefore they cry, saying, Let us go \add and\add*
sacrifice to our God.

Let there more work be laid upon the men, that they may labour
therein; and let them not regard vain words.\f + \fr 5.9  \ft Let there…: Heb. Let the work be heavy upon the
men\f*

¶ And the taskmasters of the people went out, and their officers,
and they spake to the people, saying, Thus saith Pharaoh, I will not
give you straw.

Go ye, get you straw where ye can find it: yet not ought of your
work shall be diminished.

So the people were scattered abroad throughout all the land
of Egypt to gather stubble instead of straw.

And the taskmasters hasted \add them\add*, saying, Fulfil
your works, \add your\add* daily tasks, as when there was straw.\f + \fr 5.13 
\ft your daily…: Heb. a matter of a day in his day\f*

And the officers of the children of Israel, which Pharaoh’s
taskmasters had set over them, were beaten, \add and\add* demanded,
Wherefore have ye not fulfilled your task in making brick both yesterday
and to day, as heretofore?

¶ Then the officers of the children of Israel came and cried
unto Pharaoh, saying, Wherefore dealest thou thus with thy servants?

There is no straw given unto thy servants, and they say to us,
Make brick: and, behold, thy servants \add are\add* beaten; but the
fault \add is\add* in thine own people.

But he said, Ye \add are\add* idle, \add ye are\add* idle:
therefore ye say, Let us go \add and\add* do sacrifice to the \nd LORD\nd*.

Go therefore now, \add and\add* work; for there shall no straw
be given you, yet shall ye deliver the tale of bricks.

And the officers of the children of Israel did see \add that\add* they
\add were\add* in evil \add case\add*, after it was said, Ye shall not
minish \add ought\add* from your bricks of your daily task.

¶ And they met Moses and Aaron, who stood in the way, as they came
forth from Pharaoh:

And they said unto them, The \nd LORD\nd* look upon you, and
judge; because ye have made our savour to be abhorred in the eyes
of Pharaoh, and in the eyes of his servants, to put a sword in their
hand to slay us.\f + \fr 5.21  \ft to be…: Heb. to stink\f*

And Moses returned unto the \nd LORD\nd*, and said, Lord, wherefore hast thou
\add so\add* evil entreated this people? why \add is\add* it \add that\add*
thou hast sent me?

For since I came to Pharaoh to speak in thy name, he hath done
evil to this people; neither hast thou delivered thy people at all.\f + \fr 5.23 
\ft neither…: Heb. delivering thou hast not delivered\f*

Then the \nd LORD\nd* said unto Moses, Now shalt thou see what I will
do to Pharaoh: for with a strong hand shall he let them go, and with a
strong hand shall he drive them out of his land.

And God spake unto Moses, and said unto him, I \add am\add*
the \nd LORD\nd*:\f + \fr 6.2  \ft the \+nd LORD\+nd*: or, \+nd JEHOVAH\+nd*\f*

And I appeared unto Abraham, unto Isaac, and unto Jacob, by
\add the name of\add* God Almighty, but by my name \nd JEHOVAH\nd*
was I not known to them.

And I have also established my covenant with them, to give
them the land of Canaan, the land of their pilgrimage, wherein they were
strangers.

And I have also heard the groaning of the children of Israel,
whom the Egyptians keep in bondage; and I have remembered my covenant.

Wherefore say unto the children of Israel, I \add am\add* the
\nd LORD\nd*, and I will bring you out from under the burdens of the
Egyptians, and I will rid you out of their bondage, and I will redeem
you with a stretched out arm, and with great judgments:

And I will take you to me for a people, and I will be to you a
God: and ye shall know that I \add am\add* the \nd LORD\nd* your
God, which bringeth you out from under the burdens of the Egyptians.

And I will bring you in unto the land, concerning the which I did
swear to give it to Abraham, to Isaac, and to Jacob; and I will give
it you for an heritage: I \add am\add* the \nd LORD\nd*.\f + \fr 6.8 
\ft swear: Heb. lift up my hand\f*

¶ And Moses spake so unto the children of Israel: but they hearkened
not unto Moses for anguish of spirit, and for cruel bondage.\f + \fr 6.9 
\ft anguish: Heb. shortness, or, straitness\f*
And the \nd LORD\nd* spake unto Moses, saying,

Go in, speak unto Pharaoh king of Egypt, that he let the children
of Israel go out of his land.

And Moses spake before the \nd LORD\nd*, saying, Behold, the
children of Israel have not hearkened unto me; how then shall Pharaoh
hear me, who \add am\add* of uncircumcised lips?

And the \nd LORD\nd* spake unto Moses and unto Aaron, and gave them a
charge unto the children of Israel, and unto Pharaoh king of Egypt,
to bring the children of Israel out of the land of Egypt.

¶ These \add be\add* the heads of their fathers’ houses: The
sons of Reuben the firstborn of Israel; Hanoch, and Pallu, Hezron,
and Carmi: these \add be\add* the families of Reuben.

And the sons of Simeon; Jemuel, and Jamin, and Ohad, and Jachin,
and Zohar, and Shaul the son of a Canaanitish woman: these \add are\add*
the families of Simeon.

¶ And these \add are\add* the names of the sons of Levi according to their
generations; Gershon, and Kohath, and Merari: and the years of the
life of Levi \add were\add* an hundred thirty and seven years.

The sons of Gershon; Libni, and Shimi, according to their
families.

And the sons of Kohath; Amram, and Izhar, and Hebron, and
Uzziel: and the years of the life of Kohath \add were\add* an hundred
thirty and three years.

And the sons of Merari; Mahali and Mushi: these \add are\add*
the families of Levi according to their generations.

And Amram took him Jochebed his father’s sister to wife; and she
bare him Aaron and Moses: and the years of the life of Amram \add were\add*
an hundred and thirty and seven years.
¶ And the sons of Izhar; Korah, and Nepheg, and Zichri.
And the sons of Uzziel; Mishael, and Elzaphan, and Zithri.

And Aaron took him Elisheba, daughter of Amminadab, sister
of Naashon, to wife; and she bare him Nadab, and Abihu, Eleazar,
and Ithamar.

And the sons of Korah; Assir, and Elkanah, and Abiasaph: these
\add are\add* the families of the Korhites.

And Eleazar Aaron’s son took him \add one\add* of the daughters
of Putiel to wife; and she bare him Phinehas: these \add are\add*
the heads of the fathers of the Levites according to their families.

These \add are\add* that Aaron and Moses, to whom the \nd LORD\nd*
said, Bring out the children of Israel from the land of Egypt according to their
armies.

These \add are\add* they which spake to Pharaoh king of Egypt,
to bring out the children of Israel from Egypt: these \add are\add*
that Moses and Aaron.

¶ And it came to pass on the day \add when\add* the \nd LORD\nd*
spake unto Moses in the land of Egypt,

That the 
d LORD
d* spake unto Moses, saying, I \add am\add*
the 
d LORD
d*: speak thou unto Pharaoh king of Egypt all that I
say unto thee.

And Moses said before the \nd LORD\nd*, Behold, I \add am\add*
of uncircumcised lips, and how shall Pharaoh hearken unto me?

And the \nd LORD\nd* said unto Moses, See, I have made thee a
god to Pharaoh: and Aaron thy brother shall be thy prophet.

Thou shalt speak all that I command thee: and Aaron thy brother
shall speak unto Pharaoh, that he send the children of Israel out of his
land.

And I will harden Pharaoh’s heart, and multiply my signs and my
wonders in the land of Egypt.

But Pharaoh shall not hearken unto you, that I may lay my hand
upon Egypt, and bring forth mine armies, \add and\add* my people
the children of Israel, out of the land of Egypt by great judgments.

And the Egyptians shall know that I \add am\add* the \nd LORD\nd*,
when I stretch forth mine hand upon Egypt, and bring out the children
of Israel from among them.

And Moses and Aaron did as the \nd LORD\nd* commanded them, so
did they.

And Moses \add was\add* fourscore years old, and Aaron fourscore
and three years old, when they spake unto Pharaoh.
¶ And the \nd LORD\nd* spake unto Moses and unto Aaron, saying,

When Pharaoh shall speak unto you, saying, Shew a miracle for you: then thou shalt
say unto Aaron, Take thy rod, and cast \add it\add* before Pharaoh,
\add and\add* it shall become a serpent.

¶ And Moses and Aaron went in unto Pharaoh, and they did so as the
\nd LORD\nd* had commanded: and Aaron cast down his rod before Pharaoh,
and before his servants, and it became a serpent.

Then Pharaoh also called the wise men and the sorcerers: now the
magicians of Egypt, they also did in like manner with their enchantments.

For they cast down every man his rod, and they became serpents:
but Aaron’s rod swallowed up their rods.

And he hardened Pharaoh’s heart, that he hearkened not unto them; as the
\nd LORD\nd* had said.

¶ And the \nd LORD\nd* said unto Moses, Pharaoh’s heart \add is\add*
hardened, he refuseth to let the people go.

Get thee unto Pharaoh in the morning; lo, he goeth out unto the
water; and thou shalt stand by the river’s brink against he come;
and the rod which was turned to a serpent shalt thou take in thine
hand.

And thou shalt say unto him, The \nd LORD\nd* God of the Hebrews
hath sent me unto thee, saying, Let my people go, that they may serve
me in the wilderness: and, behold, hitherto thou wouldest not hear.

Thus saith the \nd LORD\nd*, In this thou shalt know that I
\add am\add* the \nd LORD\nd*: behold, I will smite with the rod that
\add is\add* in mine hand upon the waters which \add are\add* in the

and the altar, and shalt put water therein.

And thou shalt set up the court round about, and hang up the
hanging at the court gate.

And thou shalt take the anointing oil, and anoint the tabernacle, and all that
\add is\add* therein, and shalt hallow it, and all the vessels thereof: and it shall be
holy.

And thou shalt anoint the altar of the burnt offering, and all his
vessels, and sanctify the altar: and it shall be an altar most holy.\f + \fr 40.10 
\ft most holy: Heb. holiness of holinesses\f*
And thou shalt anoint the laver and his foot, and sanctify it.

And thou shalt bring Aaron and his sons unto the door of the
tabernacle of the congregation, and wash them with water.

And thou shalt put upon Aaron the holy garments, and anoint
him, and sanctify him; that he may minister unto me in the priest’s
office.
And thou shalt bring his sons, and clothe them with coats:

And thou shalt anoint them, as thou didst anoint their father,
that they may minister unto me in the priest’s office: for their
anointing shall surely be an everlasting priesthood throughout their
generations.

Thus did Moses: according to all that the \nd LORD\nd* commanded
him, so did he.

¶ And it came to pass in the first month in the second year,
on the first \add day\add* of the month, \add that\add* the tabernacle
was reared up.

And Moses reared up the tabernacle, and fastened his sockets,
and set up the boards thereof, and put in the bars thereof, and reared
up his pillars.

And he spread abroad the tent over the tabernacle, and put
the covering of the tent above upon it; as the \nd LORD\nd* commanded
Moses.

¶ And he took and put the testimony into the ark, and set the

And he brought the ark into the tabernacle, and set up the
vail of the covering, and covered the ark of the testimony; as the
\nd LORD\nd* commanded Moses.

And he put the altar of burnt offering \add by\add* the door

¶ And he set the laver between the tent of the congregation

And Moses and Aaron and his sons washed their hands and their

When they went into the tent of the congregation, and when they came

And he reared up the court round about the tabernacle and the
altar, and set up the hanging of the court gate. So Moses finished

¶ Then a cloud covered the tent of the congregation, and the
glory of the \nd LORD\nd* filled the tabernacle.

And Moses was not able to enter into the tent of the congregation,
because the cloud abode thereon, and the glory of the \nd LORD\nd*
filled the tabernacle.

And when the cloud was taken up from over the tabernacle,
the children of Israel went onward in all their journeys:\f + \fr 40.36 
\ft went onward: Heb. journeyed\f*

But if the cloud were not taken up, then they journeyed not till the
day that it was taken up.

For the cloud of the \nd LORD\nd* \add was\add* upon the tabernacle
by day, and fire was on it by night, in the sight of all the house
of Israel, throughout all their journeys.
